Bjarne Andersen wrote:
> Our main challenge is that we need the queues sperated on TLD (foo.com 
> and bar.com) to use the quota-enforcer to limit number of bytes on each 
> TLD but at the same time calculate politeness based on the IP-number so 
> that thousands of TLDs on the same IP-number does not overload the server.
> Will this be easier to implement with heritrix 3.x ??

FYI, we've started to use the term 'assignment-level-domain' (or
'ALD') for what you're calling 'TLD' here. Of course, a true 'TLD' is
only the last/'topmost' domain, such as .COM or .DK. And the
'second-level-domain' isn't necessarily the level of
assignment/hostname-sale -- it's sometimes 3rd-level, and occasionally
even 4th- or more. So 'assignment-level-domain' can be used to
communicate: whatever level has been registered/sold by a registrar to a
single entity.

H3 isn't going to solve this issue outright, but does open a few new 
possibilities, because the politeness delay is calculated outside the 
frontier, and thus easily adjustable by a custom Processor (instead of 
deeper frontier customization). Also, the ScriptedProcessor can be 
customized in Javascript/Beanshell/Groovy without requiring any Java 
changes or new libraries.

For example, one of the workarounds we've sometimes applied manually 
after noticing there's a problem is setting a much-longer politeness 
delay for affected domains. Then the average rate certain IPs are hit 
stays reasonable -- even though it's not as strictly enforced as the 
built-in politeness mechanism.

Code to automate this process could in H3 be dropped in as an optional 
custom Processor -- increasing delays on any queue that it notices (via 
its own rolling tracking) is offering URLs against an over-trafficked IP.

Another thing you could consider -- in H1 or H3 -- is trying the 
existing IPQueueAssignmentPolicy, for exact IP-based politeness, but 
replacing or extending QuotaEnforcer so that it bases its cutoff 
decision on a separate tally that is completely independent of the 
frontier queue-groupings.

This might be a good idea because overloading the frontier queues to 
serve as both the atom of serialized-request/politeness calculations, 
and other reporting/allocation decisions, will always involve some 
tradeoffs/conflicts. (For example, what if you've arranged both 
A.FOO.COM and B.FOO.COM to go into a single FOO.COM ALD frontier queue 
-- but B.FOO.COM is on a completely different, perhaps overloaded or 
unresponsive host. Connection timeouts or politeness delays applied 
because of B.FOO.COM's behavior might then interfere with the collection 
of A.FOO.COM URLs more than you'd like.)

We may yet come up with a good design for freely mixing whatever 
queue-groupings are most convenient with other completely-orthogonal 
politeness/quota rules... but investigation so far suggests that's hard 
to do without making the frontier even more complicated, and adding new 
risks of deadlock or imbalanced progress. I hope the ideas above can 
help in the meantime.

> John pretty much sums up the problem.
> 
> The way I've dealt with this has been on a case by case basis. Each time 
> we detect this situation, we override the frontier's 
> "force-queue-assignment" setting to ensure that all the domains are 
> dumped in the same politeness bucket.
> 
> This is quite simple when you are dealing with a multitude of 
> sub-domains as you can just throw in the override on the parent domain.
> 
> - Kris

>  > It is not actually possible to guarantee this.
>  > There is no real way to distinguish for sure where the actual physical
>  > hardware that hosts a name is.
>  >
>  > There has been some discussion of adding IP addresses to the politeness
>  > capability, which
>  > would do some of it.
>  >
>  > But, that would be defeated if the provider doing the service has given
>  > separate IP addresses
>  > to each virtual server, e.g. as would be done if they had ssl clients on
>  > each virtual machine.
>  >
>  > Another thing that can be considered is to extend politeness behavior
>  > into parent domains,
>  > e.g. act polite across all of:
>  > *.foo.com
>  >
>  > Which would again handle some of it, if the virtual servers all had a
>  > common parent.
>  > Of course, this would be wrong for large scale domains spread across
>  > multiple disparate
>  > locations.
>  >
>  > If your scope is relatively small, you can also put those things you
>  > detect as virtual servers in a separate
>  > crawl job, turn off in the other job, increase the inter arrival time,
>  > and limit the number of threads to slow it all down.
>  >
>  > These are all workarounds for the problem, that may help a little.
>  > There are probably others you can try.
>  >
>  > Its just that the Internet architecture was designed such that the
>  > bandwidth limiting
>  > should happen lower in the stack, like at the border router to that
>  > actual virtualized machine,
>  > or on the overloaded host itself, and most ISPs have no incentive to do
>  > so. (Some guy is using extra bandwidth, so I
>  > can bill more? Great. . .) Or no clue that they even should.
>  >
